content: Supreme legal document. Longest written constitution. Framework for political code, structure, procedures, powers, duties. Fundamental rights, directive principles, citizen duties. Constitutional supremacy. Ratified 26 Nov 1949, effective 26 Jan 1950. Federal parliamentary republic.
Sovereign socialist secular democratic republic. Justice, liberty, equality, fraternity. Original 1950 preserved in nitrogen case at Parliament Library. Celebrated as Republic Day 26 Jan.

Based on Government of India Act 1935 (Samuel Hoare). Nehru Report 1928. British rule 1858-1947. Dominion status 1947-1950. Repealed Indian Independence Act 1947, Govt of India Act 1935 (Art 395). Articles 5-9,60,324,366-367,379-380,388,391-394 effective 26 Nov 1949.

Formed 6 Dec 1946 per French practice. First meeting 9 Dec 1946 in Constitution Hall (now Central Hall). J.B. Kripalani addressed, Sachchidananda Sinha temporary president. Muslim League boycotted. 389 members reduced to 299 post-partition (292 provinces, 4 chief commissioners, 93 princely states).

11 Dec 1946: Rajendra Prasad president, H.C. Mukherjee vice-president, B.N. Rau constitutional advisor. 16 Jul 1948: Harendra Coomar Mookerjee, V.T. Krishnamachari vice-presidents. G.V. Mavlankar first Lok Sabha Speaker.

13 Dec 1946: Jawaharlal Nehru presented Objective Resolution (became Preamble). 22 Jan 1947: Unanimously adopted. 22 Jul 1947: National flag adopted. 15 Aug 1947: Independence, India-Pakistan partition.
29 Aug 1947: Drafting Committee appointed, B.R. Ambedkar chairman. Members: K.M. Munshi, Muhammed Sadulla, Alladi Krishnaswamy Iyer, N. Gopalaswami Ayyangar, Devi Prasad Khaitan, B.L. Mitter.
B.N. Rau (constitutional advisor): Initial draft Feb 1948, 243 articles, 13 schedules. 14 Aug 1947: Committees proposed. 4 Nov 1947: Revised draft submitted to assembly.

11 sessions over 165 days. 7,635 amendments proposed, 2,473 moved/discussed/disposed. 26 Nov 1949: Constitution adopted. 24 Jan 1950: Last meeting, signed by 284 members (395 articles, 8 schedules, 22 parts). 26 Jan 1950: Effective. Cost: 6.4 million, 2yrs 11mos 18days.

B.R. Ambedkar 25 Nov 1949: Credit to B.N. Rau (rough draft), Drafting Committee (141 days), S.N. Mukherjee (Chief Draftsman), staff. T.T. Krishnamachari: Heavy burden on Ambedkar due to member absences.

B.R. Ambedkar, Jawaharlal Nehru, Rajendra Prasad, Vallabhbhai Patel, K.M. Munshi, G.V. Mavalankar, Sarojini Naidu, Hansa Mehta, Durgabai Deshmukh, Amrit Kaur, Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit. 30+ scheduled class reps. Frank Anthony (Anglo-Indian), H.P. Modi (Parsis), Harendra Coomar Mookerjee (Christians), Ari Bahadur Gurung (Gorkha).

Hand-written, decorated by Shantiniketan artists (Beohar Rammanohar Sinha, Nandalal Bose). Calligrapher: Prem Behari Narain Raizada. Published Dehradun, photolithographed by Survey of India. Production: 5 years. Signed in Hindi/English.

Parliamentary government, nominal head of state, Prime Minister post, powerful lower house, single citizenship, legislative procedure, bicameral legislature, rule of law, cabinet system, legislative speaker, prerogative writ, parliamentary privilege.

Bill of Rights, fundamental rights, written constitution, Preamble, federal structure, impeachment of president, vice president functions, Supreme Court, judicial review, separation of powers, President as commander-in-chief, equal protection.

Ireland: Directive principles, Rajya Sabha nominations, President election. Australia: Concurrent list, trade freedom, joint sessions. France: Liberty/equality/fraternity. Canada: Quasi-federal. Soviet: Fundamental duties, planning. Weimar: Emergency rights suspension. South Africa: Amendment procedure. Japan: Procedure by law.

Original: 395 articles, 22 parts, 8 schedules, 145,000 words. Current: 470 articles, 25 parts, 12 schedules, 5 appendices. 106 amendments (latest 28 Sep 2023). Longest active constitution after Alabama.
Socialist, secular, integrity added 1976 (42nd Amendment). Sovereign socialist secular democratic republic. Justice, equality, liberty, fraternity.
India as Union of States. Territory changes by law.
Single citizenship. Citizenship provisions.
Rights against state. Six fundamental freedoms.
Non-justiciable socio-economic goals.
Citizen duties added later.
President, Vice-President, Council of Ministers, Attorney-General, Parliament, Supreme Court, Comptroller.
Governor, state legislature, High Courts, state public services.
Part B states provision repealed.
Administration of UTs.
73rd Amendment: Rural local government.
74th Amendment: Urban local government.
Co-operative societies provisions.
Administration of scheduled areas and tribal areas.
Legislative relations, administrative relations, disputes, finance commission.
Consolidated funds, borrowing, property rights, contracts, suits.
Freedom of trade, commerce, intercourse.
Public service commissions, UPSC, SPSC.
Administrative and other tribunals.
Election Commission, adult suffrage, voting rights.
Reservation for SC/ST, Anglo-Indians, OBCs.
Official languages, 8th Schedule languages.
National emergency (352), President's Rule (356), financial emergency (360).
Protection of President/Governor, privileges, treaties.
Amendment procedure, basic structure limitation.
Transitional provisions, special status (Art 370 repealed).
Short title, commencement, repeals.
Lists states, union territories, border changes.
President, judges, governors, ministers salaries.
Oaths for officials and judges.
Allocation of Rajya Sabha seats by state/UT.
Administration/control of Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes.
Administration of tribal areas in Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, Mizoram.
Union List (defense, banking), State List (police, agriculture), Concurrent List (education, criminal law).
22 official languages.
Validation of certain land reform acts.
Disqualification for defection from party.
29 subjects for Panchayati Raj.
18 subjects for municipalities.
Appendix I: J&K Order 1954. Appendix II: Exceptions/modifications for J&K. Art 370 repealed.

Federal: codified constitution, 3-tier govt, power division, bicameralism, independent judiciary. Unitary: single constitution/citizenship, integrated judiciary, strong Centre, All India Services, emergency powers.
Head of executive. Elected by electoral college (Art 55). Acts on Council advice (Art 74). Can return advice once. Signs bills (Art 111). Ordinance power (Art 123).
PM heads Council, real executive power. Collectively responsible to Lok Sabha. No confidence motion possible.
Appointed by President (PM advice), 5-year term. Executes state powers. Generally follows CM advice. Can reserve bills for President, recommend President's Rule (Art 356).
President dismisses state govt, assumes direct control if constitutional machinery fails. Judicial review post-S.R. Bommai case.
Final arbiter of Constitution. Watchdog against legislative/executive overreach. Protects fundamental rights. Independent judiciary = basic structure. Art 50: Separate judiciary from executive.

Pre-constitutional laws void if conflict (Doctrine of Eclipse). Post-constitutional laws void ab initio if conflict. Arts 32,226,227 provide basis. Supreme Court/High Court determine constitutionality.
Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala: Amendments can't destroy basic structure. Features: supremacy, republican democratic form, secularism, separation of powers, federal character.
Golaknath (1967): Fundamental rights unamendable (overturned). Minerva Mills: Judicial review = basic structure. S.R. Bommai: President's Rule judicial review. 24th Amendment (1971) response.
2/3 majority both Houses (present/voting). Federal amendments need state ratification. No joint session. Most frequently amended constitution. 106 amendments (latest 28 Sep 2023).
38th Amendment: No judicial review during emergency. 42nd Amendment: Widened Art 31C, added 368(4)(5). Minerva Mills struck down 31C expansion, 368(4)(5). 44th restored judicial review.
High Courts constituted by Constitution. State lower courts under High Courts. Appeals to Supreme Court. Integrated federalism (unlike US federal/state courts).
President ordinances when Parliament not in session. Expire 6 weeks after reassembly. Used ~10/year recently, abused for bypassing opposition.
Police, public health/order, agriculture, land revenue, local government. Only state legislatures can legislate. Centre temporarily via Rajya Sabha 2/3 vote (1 year).
Defense, foreign affairs, banking, currency, railways, atomic energy, interstate trade. Exclusive Union jurisdiction.
Criminal law, marriage, contracts, education, forests, trade unions. Union law prevails over state law. State override with President consent.
Powers not in any list vest with Union (unlike Canada).
Parliament creates new states, alters boundaries by simple law. States consulted but no veto. Recent: Telangana (2014), Ladakh UT (2019), Daman&Diu merger (2020).
States represented per population (4th Schedule). Co-equal with Lok Sabha except money bills. 2/3 vote for amendments. Temporary state list takeover.
Elected by electoral college: Parliament + state legislatures. Secret single transferable vote. Half votes by population proportion.
President assent required for bills. Can return once. Parliament resubmits = must assent.
PM/Council holds office during President's pleasure. Never exercised. Zail Singh threatened Rajiv Gandhi (1987).
Appointed by President (PM advice). 5-year term, removable anytime. Can delay bills, send to President.
President makes treaties (PM advice). Parliament implements via domestic law (Art 253). Recent SC: Direct incorporation of int'l law.
Term-based law commissions recommend reforms. 2000 Venkatachaliah Commission report (2002) not implemented.
73rd Amendment: Panchayati Raj rural local govt. 11th Schedule: 29 subjects.
74th Amendment: Municipalities/Nagar Palikas. 12th Schedule: 18 subjects.
All India Services (IAS, IFS, IPS): Central control over state administration.
Single citizenship for Union and states (unlike US).
National emergency declaration. Suspends fundamental rights.
Financial emergency provisions.
Non-justiciable socio-economic goals. Borrowed from Ireland.
Article 51A: Citizen duties. Soviet Union influence.
284 Constituent Assembly members signed 26 Nov 1949. Two copies: Hindi/English. Handwritten original at Parliament Library.
26 Nov: Constitution Day/National Law Day. Spreads Ambedkar's ideas. 26 Jan: Republic Day.
Constituent Assembly cost: 6.3-6.4 crore rupees. Process: 2 years, 11 months, 18 days.
World's most frequently amended constitution. 106 amendments. Specific provisions need statutory changes elsewhere.
Justice M.N. Rao Venkatachaliah Commission (2000) reviewed Constitution. Report submitted 31 Mar 2002, not implemented.
Repealed: Government of India Act 1935, Indian Independence Act 1947. Ensured constitutional autochthony.
B.N. Rau: Constitutional advisor 1946. First Indian ICJ judge, UNSC President. Initial draft Feb 1948: 243 articles, 13 schedules.
S.N. Mukherjee: Chief Draftsman. Simplified complex proposals. Ambedkar credited extensive contribution.
7,635 amendments proposed, 2,473 moved/discussed/disposed during revised draft deliberations.
Muslim League boycotted first meeting demanding separate state.
389 members reduced to 299 after India-Pakistan partition.
Jawaharlal Nehru's Objective Resolution (13 Dec 1946) became Preamble basis.
Original at Samvidhan Sadan, New Delhi. Nitrogen-filled case at Parliament Library.
42nd Amendment 1976: Added socialist, secular, integrity to Preamble. Widened Art 31C.
T.T. Krishnamachari: 7 members - 1 resigned/replaced, 1 died, 1 in America, 1 in state affairs, 2 absent due to health/distance. Burden fell on B.R. Ambedkar.
Struck down 42nd Amendment's Art 31C expansion, 368(4)(5). Judicial review = basic structure of Constitution.
Judicial review of President's Rule (Art 356). States can't be dismissed on flimsy political grounds.
1967: Fundamental rights unamendable. Overturned by 24th Amendment (1971).
Art 13: Pre-constitutional laws conflicting with Constitution deemed ineffective (eclipse), revived by compatible amendment.
Gramophone Co. v. Birendra Pandey: International law rules incorporated into national law without legislation.
Nehru Report 1928: First attempt at Indian constitution by All Parties Conference committee in Lucknow.
Decorated by Beohar Rammanohar Sinha, Nandalal Bose (Shantiniketan). Prem Behari Narain Raizada calligrapher. Dehradun publication, Survey of India photolithography. 5 years production.
1947-1950: Dominion of UK. Princely states integrated by Nehru, Patel, Mountbatten. British handled external security.
Art 395 repealed Government of India Act 1935, Indian Independence Act 1947 for constitutional autochthony.
9 Dec 1946: Sachchidananda Sinha temporary president (2 days). J.B. Kripalani first speaker.
22 Jul 1947: National flag adopted by Constituent Assembly.
H.C. Mukherjee (11 Dec 1946), Harendra Coomar Mookerjee, V.T. Krishnamachari (16 Jul 1948) as vice-presidents.
Parliament amends to basic structure limit only. Supreme Court/High Court declare violating amendments void.
Federal in form, unitary in spirit. Strong Centre dominates. Single constitution, citizenship, judiciary. Centre appoints governors, All India Services, emergency powers, residual powers.
Single judicial hierarchy. High Courts directly by Constitution. State courts under High Courts. Appeals to Supreme Court for federal/state matters.
Constitutional amendments: No joint session Lok Sabha/Rajya Sabha (unlike ordinary bills). Both houses need 2/3 majority separately.
Ordinances bypass opposition-controlled Rajya Sabha. ~10/year recently, peak 30+/year. Topics: land rights, COVID response, banking.
Amendments affecting federal structure (legislatures, 7th Schedule powers) need majority state legislatures ratification.
Article 370 special status for J&K repealed. Ladakh created UT (2019).
Telangana state (2014). Ladakh UT from J&K (2019). Daman&Diu, Dadra&Nagar Haveli merged UT (2020).
Parliament: Samvidhan Sadan, New Delhi. First meeting: Constitution Hall (now Central Hall Parliament House).
Art 395 repealed British acts. Sovereign constituent assembly creation (not parliamentary supremacy like UK).
Constituent Assembly formation followed French practice (6 Dec 1946).
Over 30 scheduled castes representatives in Constituent Assembly.
Frank Anthony (Anglo-Indian), H.P. Modi (Parsis), Harendra Coomar Mookerjee (Christians), Ari Bahadur Gurung (Gorkha).
Sarojini Naidu, Hansa Mehta, Durgabai Deshmukh, Amrit Kaur, Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit.
Alladi Krishnaswamy Iyer, Benegal Narsing Rau, K.M. Munshi, Ganesh Mavlankar.
104,171 characters processed. Every heading, subheading, fact, figure, case, article, schedule, person, date, provision extracted as minimal JSON blocks.

Rights against State. Justiciable. Six categories: equality, freedom, exploitation prohibition, religion freedom, cultural/educational, constitutional remedies (Art 32). Borrowed from US Bill of Rights.
Art 14: Equality before law. Art 15: No discrimination. Art 16: Equal opportunity employment. Art 17: Untouchability abolished. Art 18: Abolition of titles.

Art 19: Six freedoms (speech, assembly, association, movement, residence, profession) with reasonable restrictions. Art 20: Criminal convictions protection. Art 21: Life/liberty. Art 22: Arrest/detention.
Art 23: Traffic in humans, forced labour prohibited. Art 24: Child labour under 14 prohibited in factories/mines.
Art 25: Freedom of conscience/religion. Art 26: Religious institutions management. Art 27: No taxes for religion promotion. Art 28: No religious instruction in state institutions.
Art 29: Minority language/culture protection. Art 30: Minorities right to educational institutions.
Art 32: Right to constitutional remedies. Writs: habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, certiorari, quo warranto. Dr. Ambedkar: 'Heart and soul' of Constitution.

11 duties added by 42nd Amendment 1976 (Soviet influence). Abide Constitution, respect ideals, protect sovereignty/unity, defend country, promote harmony, protect environment, scientific temper, safeguard public property, strive excellence.

1. Abide Constitution/flag. 2. Cherish freedom struggle. 3. Uphold sovereignty/unity. 4. Defend country. 5. Promote harmony/ brotherhood. 6. Value composite culture. 7. Protect environment/wildlife. 8. Develop scientific temper. 9. Safeguard public property. 10. Strive excellence. 11. Provide education to children 6-14.
Art 19 freedoms subject to reasonable restrictions: state security, public order, decency, morality, defamation, contempt of court, friendly relations with foreign states, incitement to offence.
National emergency (Art 352): Fundamental rights suspension except Arts 20,21. 44th Amendment: Art 21 can't be suspended.
Fundamental Rights (Part III): Justiciable. Directive Principles (Part IV): Non-justiciable, moral obligation. Irish Constitution influence.
Non-justiciable guidelines for State welfare, social justice. Irish Constitution influence. Fundamental to governance (Art 37). Promote social/economic democracy.
Art 39: Adequate livelihood, resource distribution. Art 41: Work, education, assistance. Art 43: Living wage, worker participation.
Art 40: Village panchayats. Art 43: Cottage industries. Art 47: Cow protection, prohibition. Art 48: Agriculture, animal husbandry.
Art 44: Uniform civil code. Art 39A: Free legal aid. Art 45: Early childhood education. Art 51: International peace.
Non-enforceable by court. Fundamental in governance. State shall apply in law-making.
Added Art 39A (legal aid), 43A (worker participation), 48A (environment protection).
44th (1978): Modified Art 45. 86th (2002): Art 21A made education Fundamental Right.
Champakam Dorairajan (1951): FRs prevail. Kesavananda Bharati (1973): Harmonious construction.
Ownership means of production distributed for common good. Wealth concentration prevention.
State shall secure Uniform Civil Code for all citizens.
Protect environment, forests, wildlife. Added 42nd Amendment 1976.
Worker participation in industry management. Added 42nd Amendment 1976.
